profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Norwich, Conn., June 17, 1793; pursued classical studies; studied medicine; moved to New York State in 1811; abandoned medicine and studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Buffalo, N.Y., in 1815; elected to the Sixteenth, Seventeenth, and Eighteenth Congresses (March 4, 1819-March 3, 1825); chairman, Committee on Expenditures in the Department of the Treasury (Seventeenth Congress); member of the State senate 1830-1837; unsuccessful Whig candidate for election to the United States Senate in 1839; died in Buffalo, N.Y., September 19, 1859; interment in Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo, N.Y.

note.content: One of two elected to represent the 21st district.

researchRecord.name: 1815, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Albert Tracy to his brother, Phineas L. Tracy, written on April 30, 1815. In the letter, Tracy writes concerning national and New York politics and the War of 1812.

researchRecord.name: 1815-1851, 3 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains 254 items, the bulk of the papers being letters to Albert Tracy. Among the correspondents are Millard Fillmore (7 letters), Martin Van Buren (4 letters), William Henry Seward (17 letters), Thurlow Weed (17 letters), John Spencer (23 letters), Silas Wright (15 letters), DeWitt Clinton (2 letters), William L. Marcy (3 letters), Lewis Cass (5 letters) and others. The letters give many insights into the politics and government of New York State and the nation (especially the Anti-Masonic and Whig Parties) during the 1830's and 1840's. Although Tracy did not hold office after 1838, he continued to have an influence on political events, as the letters of this era indicate. There are also some letters from Tracy, some to his wife and other miscellaneous items in the collection. (ca 25 items).

researchRecord.name: 1817-1858, 9 items.
researchRecord.description: Letters: Albany, to Ebenezer Averill, Buffalo, 30 Dec. 1824, on Albert Tracy's proposed bill to pay for the pasturage and fuel supplied by Averill; Buffalo, to I. & J. Townsend, Albany, 25 Nov. 1829, informing them of the availability of a house and lot on Washington Street in Buffalo; Albany, to Absalom Bull, Black Rock, 4 Feb. and 11 Feb. 1833, regarding Tracy's proposed bill to extend the time in which public officials must take the oath of office; Albany, to Ralph Plumb, Lodi, Cattaraugus County, 22 Jan. 1834, on the efforts of the Holland Land Company to force settlers to pay a tax imposed by the legislature; a printed circular letter, Norwich, Conn., to "fellow citizens of Collins, Erie County, New York", 25 July 1840, giving his view of the upcoming election as a choice between a national bank and an independent treasury; and Buffalo, to Vine Wright Kingsley, New York, on Tracy's definition of government. Also, a receipt concerning notes of Benjamin W. Hopkins and Henry Daw, 1817, signed by Tracy as attorney for the plaintiffs..

recordLocation.name: Buffalo and Erie County Historical Society

researchRecord.name: In the Albert Tracy Papers, 1843-1893, 0.5 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Prominent correspondents include Albert H. Tracy. The collection also is available on microfilm.
